column2: The Corliss Engine was an improvement over previous stationary steam engines. Its main features were separate valves for letting steam into and out of the cylinder, and systems for controlling their timing as to regulate engine operation. It offered significantly higher energy efficiency than earlier engines, requiring less coal to perform work.

A compound steam engine is one where steam is led to expand in several consecutive cylinders, allowing a larger fraction of the thermal energy of the steam to be converted to mechanical work, thus enabling higher energy efficiency.

Generating electricity and using it to power industrial machinery offers key advantages over transmitting power mechanically. Electricity can be transmitted in a highly precise, controlled way over long distances, providing just the right amount of power just where it is needed, resulting in both higher energy efficiency and greater versatility.

Heavy fuel oil is a product of oil refining unsuitable for use in internal combustion engines. Instead, it is useful as a complement to coal in powering steam engines, not just substituting for part of the coal but making it ignite easier too.
Steam locomotives allowed for powered rail transport, replacing animal power with a more economic alternative.
Developments in Diesel engine design eventually made them feasible for use in locomotives, offering an alternative to steam power that is more economical in many situations.
A cotton mill weaves, bleaches, dyes and looms cotton into fabric. It is arguably the factory that started the whole Industrial Revolution.
A wool mill weaves, bleaches, dyes and looms wool from wool-producing livestock into fabric.
A lumber mill saws raw timber into lumber. Lumber is used to build a wide range of things, from countryside houses to kitchen tables to warships.

Steam tractors bring steam power beyond the reach of stationary factory engines or railroad locomotives, whether it means pulling hauls on a road, agricultural machines on a field, or being hitched to machines to provide input torque.
The internal combustion engine made tractors truly come into their own, offering both superior power to weight and more precise control of output power than earlier steam-powered tractors.

Canning is the preservation of food by temporarily sterilizing it and sealing it in airtight metal cans. It is a relatively convenient and cost-efficient method of food preservation and thus, canned food is used to feed urban populations and troops in the field. This factory turns livestock into canned food.

Canning is the preservation of food by temporarily sterilizing it and sealing it in airtight metal cans. It is a relatively convenient and cost-efficient method of food preservation and thus, canned food is used to feed urban populations and troops in the field. This factory turns fish into canned food.
A paper mill uses chemicals to break down timber into a fibrous pulp, which is then reformed into sheets of paper. Paper is used mainly for bookkeeping and distribution of the written word.
This factory turns iron and chemicals into a wide range of different types of ammunition, from rifle cartridges to artillery shells.
Furniture is made here from lumber. It is a necessity for every home and thus in demand by the entire population regardless of income.
A printing press imprints the written word onto paper, using chemicals such as inks and pigments, producing goods such as books, newspapers and propaganda pamphlets.
This factory uses fabric to produce cheap, utilitarian clothing for the general populace.

The cotton gin (engine) is a machine for mechanical separation of cotton seeds from the fibre. It was critical for making cotton an economically viable raw material for the mass production of textiles.

Even as steam-powered warships rendered sailships obsolete for combat, sailships retained their usefulness for merchant shipping due to requiring no fuel for propulsion. Building sailships requires lumber for the hull and fabric for the sails and the rigging.
Advances in iron working made all-iron rail feasible, allowing for heavier loads than previous rail designs that used a combination of wood and iron.

Advances in steel manufacturing made it economically feasible to produce and use steel rail. It allowed for even heavier loads than iron rail, and the higher cost of steel was more than worth it due to the much reduced wear suffered by the rails.

Transportation along rivers is more economical than along roads due to the lack of friction losses, even in case the cargo needs to be towed on a barge by draft animals on the riverbank. Thus, civilization has predominantly developed around waterways. The question is, though, why settle for what nature has given you when you can make your own? The industrial age saw an expansion of canal networks in order to efficiently bring in raw materials to the growing industrial cities.

Advances in civil engineering allowed for reliable construction of tunnels large enough for rail and road transportation. Being able to go under or through obstacles makes, quite literally, another dimension available for infrastructure design.

A rack railway is a railway where a cogwheel on the train engages a toothed rail, typically an additional third rail in the middle. It allows for trains to climb steeper slopes, opening up more areas for rail transport.

Previously, transportation services would largely run according to demand, and departures happen whenever there was a sufficient amount of cargo or passengers. The move to timetable-based running improved reliability and allowed for better operative coordination by rail transport companies and their customers alike, and reduced time wasted waiting.

Concentrating industrial activity to predefined districts with their own dedicated railway stations allows for trains to get almost all the way to the doorstep of the factory. It also improves air quality in the districts where workers live.

The proliferation of high-speed road vehicles caused traffic planners an additional consideration: Interference to traffic caused by slowdowns at intersections and crossings. The solution was to limit access to high-speed roads to a smaller number of key points and to design entries and exists so that they cause minimal interference, primarily by making users cross the paths of as few other users as possible.

Glass is produced in a coal-powered kiln from silica mixed with various minerals. It is mainly used as a consumer good in the form of windows, mirrors and glassware, but also as an industrial intermediate good.
Iron is smelted and mixed with coal to produce steel at this factory. Being used for both construction and machinery, steel is a vital resource that no emergent industrial power should be without.

Cement is made by heating clay and limestone in a kiln, and grinding it to a fine powder. It is, along with steel, the material that the growing industrial cities of the age are built of. It is used to build factories and used as a consumer good to build housing, mainly by craftsmen, clerks and capitalists.
This factory casts, bores and assembles artillery guns of various types from steel. Artillery is required to arm a navy, and is an important support weapon for an army.

Small arms are produced from steel and lumber here. As small arms are what the core of a country's army is equipped with, this factory is essential for a country striving for military self-sufficiency.

Charcoal is what you get when wood is heated while deprived of oxygen to prevent combustion. While less economically efficient than mining, charcoal-burning provides an alternative coal source for countries lacking mines of their own.

Using self-powered machinery to do work rather than doing it yourself is what industrialization is about, and this factory exists to provide that machinery. Machines are built out of steel, and need lubricant to keep friction from overheating them or wearing them apart.
Soap is what keeps people and places clean, and thus is an everyday consumer good for the entire population. In this factory, soap is made from palm oil and alkaline chemicals.

Beer has been brewed from grain since time immemorial, and this factory uses the latest industrial technology to do it more efficiently than ever before. Beer is an everyday consumer good consumed in large amounts by all strata of society.
Confectionery is a catch-all term for sweet food products: Candy, cakes, pastries, biscuits, chocolate. It is a good consumed by all strata of the population.
Wine is a luxury beverage produced by fermenting fruit. It is consumed by the rich, and by lower classes should they obtain the means to do so.
Whisky is liquor produced by fermenting grain and distilling the result. The outcome is a luxury good consumed by wealthy consumers.
The industrial age created a whole new need for reliable lubrication of machines, and palm oil is particularly well suited for the purpose. This factory turns palm oil into lubricant.
The industrial age created a whole new need for reliable lubrication of machines, and the oil of sperm whales is particularly well suited for the purpose. This factory turns fish into lubricant.

A chemical industry produces a wide range of products, such as paints, dyes, soda, lye and nitroglycerin. The chemical plant turns raw chemical minerals into refined chemicals, an input of many other factories.
This factory produces pharmaceuticals for the medical needs of the population. Everyone falls ill from time to time, though whether they can afford medication is another matter.

Microscopy and empirical epidemology lent support to the notion that diseases are transmitted by tiny lifeforms, rather than by miasma as used to be the prevailing view. The implications for public policy regarding sanitation and disease prevention are significant.

Vacuum distillation is distillation where the liquid is brought to boiling point not by heating it, but rather by bringing down the boiling point itself by reducing pressure. It allowed for the refining of high-quality lubricant from crude petroleum.
Using coal, the synthetic oil factory produces oil. Vital for nations that do not have ready access to oil but still need it badly.

A radio allows instantaneous wireless communication over long distances, and effortless reception of the same transmission by many. It is thus a whole new medium of mass communication, and a major consumer good. This factory makes radios out of electric gear.

The Carnot Cycle is a theoretical description of the operation of a heat engine, showing how the energy efficiency of the engine depends on the temperature, volume and pressure of the working fluid at different points in the engine cycle. Such understanding is important for efforts to improve engine power and efficiency.

Statistical mechanics is a field of physics dealing with how the macroscopic properties of systems are determined by the microscopic behaviour of their constituent subunits. It provides a theoretical foundation for thermodynamics.

Electric motors allow for locomotives to operate using electrically transmitted power, rather than needing to produce their own. This provides several situational advantages, particularly in that it enables the use of powered rail transportation in places where firing engines and producing smoke is unacceptable, such as confined spaces and population centres.

By enforcing adherence to one or a few railroad track widths (gauges), interconnectivity between different railway lines can be improved. Gauge standardisation is thus a first step towards integrating disparate, local railway lines operated by different companies into a nationwide network.

Rail development was originally often local, resulting over time in ownership distributed over a myriad companies of various sizes, all operating to maximize their own profits without regard for the rest of the network, many having been rendered barely viable due to economic developments since their original construction. By governmental consolidation of rail lines, either through promotion of mergers or outright nationalization, viability was improved as development could be done with regard to the whole, rather than the narrow interests of owners of small parts of it.

The theory of relativity postulates that the speed of light and the laws of physics are the same regardless of choice of frame of reference. From these seemingly modest postulates, all kinds of conclusions follow that violate certain assumptions that classical physics has so far considered self-evident. The foremost among them being that space and the passage of time are not constant and unchangeable, but can be dilated, warped and compressed.

The early 19th century saw the proliferation of thought on the subject of education, not only regarding how to effectively transmit knowledge but also regarding what objectives education should have and what social purposes it should fulfil. The work of pioneering educators such as Pestalozzi, Herbart and Diesterweg not only improved the efficiency of education but also left a lasting social impact.

The efficiency of the civil service is significantly improved by making it largely independent of the acting government. Appointment and promotion can be based on merit rather than favoritism, and the ability of the government to use the civil service as a tool against its domestic political rivals is reduced.

Keeping records of births, deaths and places of residency enables more efficient government, both as a tool for policy planning and execution, whether it's for taxing them, hauling their children to school, or drafting them for war.

Deweyan pedagogy emphasized the importance of interaction and hands-on experience of the subject being taught. Originating around the turn of the 19th to 20th century, it was the most significant contribution of its time to the field of pedagogy.

Total war is the concept of full mobilization and complete commitment of a country's human and material resources towards a war effort. More often than not, it goes along with the notion that any means necessary should be employed towards achieving victory, including unrestricted destruction of civilian targets in order to impair the ability of the enemy to continue to wage war. It is premised on a view of war as not only a means towards specific political ends, but as a national struggle of life and death where no price can be too high to achieve victory.

The advent of mass media in the form of radio and film did not only serve to expand popular consciousness. Governments that had sufficiently tight control over the new forms of media could use them to disseminate their own propaganda more effectively than before.

The idea that matter consists of indivisible elementary particles called atoms has existed since antiquity. In the 19th century, chemists had largely concluded that to be the case, as that postulate explained the mass ratios of reagents and products of chemical reactions. However, experiments carried out at the beginning of the 20th century showed that the atom might not be elementary after all, but actually consist of electrically charged constituent parts. The first model was the plum pudding model, depicting the atom as a continuous positively charged medium with smaller negatively charged electrons as discrete particles embedded in it. Other experiments suggested the concentration of positive charge to a nucleus. A development of that idea was the planetary model of the atom, wherein negative electrons orbited the nucleus like planets around the Sun. While this latter model enjoyed more empirical support, it raised the question of why the electrons do not lose energy by emitting radiation, as charged particles were known to do when being accelerated. It was the first indication that the microscopic world of elementary particles worked according to entirely different laws than the macroscopic, paving the way for the development of quantum mechanics.
Band saws offer an advantage over circular saws both in being able to make curved cuts and in having a smaller cut width, wasting less wood as sawdust.

Coffee roasting was traditionally done by the consumer at home. By industrializing the roasting process, coffee could be sold pre-roasted, offering higher consumer value to those who would rather not spend time doing it themselves.

Rotation of common food crops had been known for ages, but cotton and tobacco presented unique challenges in soil management. Finally, in the latter part of the 19th century, crop rotation schemes were finally developed for these crops, mainly using peas, peanuts and sweet potatoes for soil replenishment.

With the explosion in demand for rubber caused by the emergence of the automobile industry, harvesting of rubber from trees in the wild was no longer sufficient to meet demand. Commercial rubber farming was faced with great difficulty initially, in large part due to the planting of Amazonian rubber trees in very different environments on the other side of the world. In a few decades, however, commercial rubber farming had become the norm, and collection of wild rubber increasingly uneconomical.

By continuously adding inputs, extracting final products and regulating and adjusting the process in real-time, a chemical manufacturing process can be made much more efficient than what could be achieved using batch methods.

Pasteurization is a heat treatment that kills bacteria and breaks down enzymes that are key to the process of food spoilage. It extends the shelf life of products thus treated with only a slight effect on food taste, composition and nutritional value, and thus a useful method of food preservation.

Cracking is the breaking of large hydrocarbons into smaller parts. It allows for heavy, thick, ungainly oils to be turned into more fluid ones, increasing the fraction of crude oil that is turned into valuable fuel usable for combustion engines. Catalytic cracking is the use of chemical catalysts for the purpose, and it generally achieves a higher quality of the resulting fuel at lower energy cost than previously used thermal methods.
This was a machine that mechanically rolled molten glass into flat panes, allowing for efficient mass production of windows.
Mechanization of the act of glassblowing itself increased the output of the glassware industry tremendously.
Offering a good combination of grip, friction and smoothness of ride, the pneumatic tire quickly became the standard for wheeled vehicles and by far the most significant rubber product.

This was a process for producing calcium carbonate from limestone and saltwater, using ammonia and carbon dioxide as catalysts. It replaced the previously used, more expensive and more polluting Leblanc process that required sulphuric acid and produced calcium sulphate as a byproduct.

Electrolysis is the separation of ions in a solution through the application of an electric field and current. It can be the most economical way of extracting substances that are scarcely found in mineral deposits but abundantly dissolved in water.
By using calcium sulphate as the reactive ingredient, Portland cement yielded concrete that was both stronger and faster to settle than earlier formulas.

The rotary kiln allowed for cement to be heated with higher thermal efficiency than before, while simultaneously being mixed, with continuous feeding of raw material and removal of final cement. Its introduction increased both the quality and quantity of cement produced.

A diesel engine uses the heat produced from compression of air to ignite fuel, rather than a spark plug. A high compression ratio and air-to-fuel ratio makes the diesel engine more fuel-efficient than a gasoline engine, though at the cost of engine power, being ideal for situations where fuel efficiency is important. Furthermore, as diesel fuel can and needs to be heavier than gasoline, using diesel engines as complementary to gasoline engines allows for a larger fraction of crude oil to be used as combustion engine fuel.

The Kraft process is a chemical process using sodium hydroxide and sulfide to break down wood into pulp. Contrary to earlier processes, it allows for most of the pulping chemicals to be recovered afterwards.
Synthetic detergents can be used instead of soap for cleaning, and have several useful properties such as being less affected by hard water.

Polyvinyl chloride, better known as PVC or vinyl, is a versatile synthetic plastic polymer that is useful for a very wide range of applications, as various additives can be used to precisely fine-tune its mechanical properties.
This was the first machine that mechanized the actual rolling of cigarettes, enabling them to be cheaply mass-produced.

Smokeless powder is a projectile propellant that combusts almost completely, leaving neither ash to foul the barrel nor smoke to impair vision on the battlefield. Not having to clean the barrel between shots greatly increases potential rates of fire.

The transistor is a device with three terminals and two paths for electric current inside, with the current on one affecting the conductivity of the other. This makes it able to be used for switching and amplification, making it a key component in the developing field of electronics.
Relatively cheap and easy to produce industrially, aspirin was one of the first mass-produced pharmaceutical products.
Hydraulics is the art of the transmission of force and mechanical power by using a pressurised fluid as a medium.

Lithography is a printing method where hydrophobic and hydrophilic chemicals are used to control which parts of a printing plate ink sticks to. In many production processes, it allows for higher efficiency and versatility than using movable type.

A rotary printing press uses a rotating, cylindrical press-head to imprint images on paper. This allows for continuous paper feed and much more efficient printing than with a classical flat-surface press.
The photostat was the first optical copying machine. It allowed for efficient and reliable copying, replacing previously used chemical copying methods that were time-consuming and messy.

A lockstitch seam is one consisting of two threads on opposite sides of the cloth, held in place by being entwined at each hole made by the needle. It is a simple but very neat and durable seam, and a machine capable of quickly producing one will improve the efficiency of clothing production.
Mechanization of knitting allowed for industrial mass production of clothing made from wool yarn.

Electromagnetic shielding, twisted pairs, differential transmission, and other methods of noise reduction can be used to allow for signal transmission over longer distances, and for more precise functionality in electric systems.

The first planes were technological marvels with great symbolic but little to no practical value. Over time, however, planes developed to the point where they could reliably carry passengers and cargo, and thus commercial aviation was born.
Steam-powered boats were particularly useful for transportation along rivers and canals, where sailships lack the needed space to maneuver relative to the wind.

Chocolate was well established as a fashionable hot drink in European society at the start of the industrial age, but solid chocolate was a later invention. Hydraulic pressing enabled the removal of fat from roasted cocoa beans, leaving a powder that could be mixed with sugar and butter to create a mass that could be moldable into solid bars. Thus, a prominent product of the emerging confectionery industry was born.

Romanticism had a cultural and intellectual influence that reached far beyond art and aesthetics. Glorification of individualism stimulated demand for a freer, more liberal society, and romantic mythologization of the past contributed to the development of feelings of nationhood.
Through its depiction of the often grim and bleak realities of life in industrial society, realism served as a medium for social criticism and stimulated demand for social reform.

Increasing demand for palm oil for soap, lubrication and food led to the introduction of large-scale plantation economy in palm oil production, both in West Africa from where the palm oil originated and in Southeast Easa where it was transplanted and which would over time become the global epicenter of palm oil production.

Pomology is the field of botany concerned with the study of fruit and the cultivation of fruit-bearing plants. Advances in it in the mid to late 19th century saw the introduction of new breeds and the increase of orchard yields.

Vulcanization enabled rubber to be used to produce goods that are simultaneously elastic, waterproof and wear-resistant. This led to the appearance of a wide range of rubber goods, such as footwear, insulation, and tires. This factory turns rubber into rubber goods.
Silk is the preferred luxury textile of the age. This factory uses silk and fabric to produce luxury clothing for wealthy customers.

Manufactured cigarettes are a cheap, convenient alternative for those who cannot afford proper cigars but who are willing to pay for not having to roll their own smokes. This factory makes cigarettes out of tobacco and paper.

The industrial age created a whole new need for reliable lubrication of machines. The oil of sperm whales was particularly well suited for the purpose, and prominently used until petroleum-based lubricants became widely available. This factory uses ships to catch and haul in whales for processing into lubricant.

Through proper management, the present and future timber yield of forests can be improved. Forest management deals with matters such as choice of tree species, planned growth, culling and clear-cutting, and forest regeneration.

Crude petroleum is a mixture of different hydrocarbons. Through distillation, they can be separated into lighter and heavier fractions. This yields different oils suitable for different purposes. One of these is gasoline, ideally suited for combustion engines.

Bakelite was the first synthetic plastic, produced by reacting phenol with formaldehyde. Easily moldable, chemically inert and electrically insulating, synthetic plastics quickly became widely used as a manufacturing material.

A citadel is an exceptionally armoured part of a ship, protecting its most vital parts such as engines and ammunition magazines. Through such an uneven armour layout, higher survivability for a given weight of armour could be achieved.
Jigs are frames and other structures whose purpose is to control the position and movement of machine tools, ensuring that products are built according to standards.

column4: 'Mutter, warum haben wir noch keinen McCormick-Mähdrescher? Jeder andere hat schon einen!'\n\nIm frühen 19. Jahrhundert wurden diverse mechanische Werkzeuge für die Landwirtschaft entwickelt: zum säen, ernten, dreschen oder die Forstwirtschaft.

'Mutter, hörst du das? Da ist ein neues Ding in der Mine, welches die Steine von ganz alleine bewegt.'\n\nEine der ersten Einsätze für Dampfmaschinen war der Transport des Erzes aus den Minen. Diese frühe Entwicklung der Industriellen Revolution hat nun Einzug gehalten in die Minen von $PROVINCENAME$.

This was the first semi-automatic loom. With a single operator action, it kept weaving until the shuttle ran out of thread. Consequently, a single worker could operate several looms simultaneously, increasing productivity.

A lockstitch seam is one consisting of two threads on opposite sides of the cloth, held in place by being entwined at each hole made by the needle. It is a simple but very neat and durable seam, and a machine capable of quickly producing one will improve the efficiency of clothing production.
Die Einführung von Einspannvorrichtungen steigerte die Effizienz aller Maschinen enorm, was wiederum die Produktion der meisten Industriegüter steigerte.
Band saws offer an advantage over circular saws both in being able to make curved cuts and in having a smaller cut width, wasting less wood as sawdust.

This was the first fully automatic loom, improving on earlier semi-automatic looms by adding an automatic loading mechanism to replace empty shuttles without any operator action. It allowed a single worker to operate up to 16 looms at once.

The overlock pattern consists of two parallel seams connected by a crisscrossing third seam. It is a very durable pattern. Machines capable of producing such a pattern will efficiently produce clothing of high quality.
The assembly line enhances many manufacturing processes, but particularly ones that consist of a sequence of mechanically simple actions, such as packaging.
This was a machine that mechanically rolled molten glass into flat panes, allowing for efficient mass production of windows.
Mechanization of the act of glassblowing itself increased the output of the glassware industry tremendously.

The rotary kiln allowed for cement to be heated with higher thermal efficiency than before, while simultaneously being mixed, with continuous feeding of raw material and removal of final cement. Its introduction increased both the quality and quantity of cement produced.
By using calcium sulphate as the reactive ingredient, Portland cement yielded concrete that was both stronger and faster to settle than earlier formulas.

Smokeless powder is gunpowder that combusts almost completely, leaving neither ash to foul the barrel nor smoke to impair vision on the battlefield. Not having to clean the barrel between shots greatly increases potential rates of fire.

The Kraft process is a chemical process using sodium hydroxide and sulfide to break down wood into pulp. Contrary to earlier processes, it allows for most of the pulping chemicals to be recovered afterwards. Simply put, our paper industry has developed a way to have its cake and eat it too!
Relatively cheap and easy to produce industrially, aspirin was one of the first mass-produced pharmaceutical products.

Electromagnetic shielding, twisted pairs, differential transmission, and other methods of noise reduction can be used to allow for signal transmission over longer distances, and for more precise functionality in electric systems.
Cracking is the breaking of large hydrocarbons into smaller parts. It allows for heavy, thick, ungainly oils to be turned into more fluid ones, improving the quality of refined fuel.

A vacuum tube is a device where thermal emission is used to cause a controllable current. Different kinds of vacuum tubes can, in a fairly rudimentary way, fulfil the function of a diode or a transistor, allowing for actual electronics for the first time.
